comments.commentBody:
You sure got that right, Mary! Even that finger wagging meanie from Arizona fell in line today when she approved Arizona's participation in the ACA. She said she couldn't justify not doing it, from the moral stand-point.

Whatever it is that caused her change of heart, she should bottle and share it with the Congressional GOP!

sorry, no. i dont want a nerdy economist on the Daily Show to explain the jokes arent funny any more than I want a NASA physicist in the middle of a Star Trek episode to explain warp speed isnt possible. duh. Krugman understands comedy like Stwart understands economics. i say that will all respect as a nerdy economist myself.

Well, you've essentially said what I was about to.

I would add that it's fascinating that overt rudeness has attained a certain cachet among the Republican right. Seems to establish a type of bona fides, similar to becoming a made man among those of another venal set. I have to wonder if it reflects a certain prejudice...

In addition, these people bleat about national pride and vanity to the high blue yonder, yet in reality reflect not a whit of national respect. Nor care.

Personally, I marvel at how this man can keep his frustration in tow.  And why he would want to talk to the press or the right wing escapes me.  His dignity and grace is something you and the right wing will never be able to duplicate.  No matter how much the GOP wants to hang around with the rich and be associated with them, the GOP really is the poor white trash in trailer parks, gun-toting, racist and living on taxpayer dollars in the form of food stamps, medicaid, unemployment, with daughters having babies out of wedlock.  Politicians like McConnell who have built up their wealth of $17 million during their stints in Congress are just white trash from Kentucky in all other aspects of governing.  Obama does not need to "lead" by schmoozing.  And personally I would choose to avoid schmoozing with these types.

Your last two paragraphs make it clear that the rest of this column totally gets it wrong. The GOP simply refuses to do anything that acknowledges the legitimacy of Obama's Presidency.

They can't even allow themselves to be seen with him celebrating a college basketball championship.

Obama's personality is irrelevant to this issue, and if you are going to argue that comity is this important, you are talking to the wrong side.

The "problem" is that a Court or Lane is usually a short, lightly traveled road. An avenue, in contrast, is often a major thoroughfare (think NYC).

-- jpgaskell
.

We've seen a lot about how boomers' 401ks aren't large enough, but I don't think I've seen any figures on many have had to drain their retirement accounts to live on while unemployed. I suspect it is a lot of people, and I suspect a lot of people have also been forced to taking Social Security at 62, leaving them in dire shape for the future. I don't think the full story of the plight of this generation going into old age has yet been told.
A janitorial business? Is this a joke?

Don't you read the news? Public employees are getting laid off every day.

Some people just have to have a scapegoat.

If you read this article and think the people in the film deserve what happened to them, then you have been blinded by prejudice and your own resentful nature.

What percentage of Boomers do you think were in a position to pull up corporate ladders behind them?

YOur parents obviously spoiled the bejesus out of you - greedy selfish, judgemental...yep typical Boomer brat you are.

The ones in charge who dumped pensions, who created RIFs (reductions in force) with mass layoffs....all that stuff that began in 1980s - were not the people age 17-34. . And the companies were headed up by the WWII generation and the Korean War generation (always forget them don't you? - they are in their mid to late 70s now.)

People who were only 17-34 when Reagan was elected didn't exactly have much power then. (And what is it your parents did you so love to hate? What did they do? Make you help pay for college?)

And Recessionista? The Boomers - over 80% - were TOO YOUNG TO VOTE for Nixon!! They were only 9 -26 years old!

Nixon was the darling of the WWII generation and Korean War generation and late 1950s generation who came of age back then.

You are holding yourself back with your inability to do arthimetic! Must be a Boomer progeny eh? Mommy never made you do your math homework!
The people who lived in the tenements of 100 years ago were worked like pack animals until they unionized and fought for a piece of the pie. They proved that a better world is possible.

Boomers have never been the majority of voters - no generation ever is. And they did not vote differently from the generations before and after them.

I don't buy into all this generation stuff, but for those who do I find it fascinating how Gen-X, approaching age 50 now, still presents itself as helpless children living in the shadow of their elders. They've been adults for up to 30 years now, but absolve themselves of responsibility for anything. How much longer are people going to pretend that the Boomers are to blame for everything that's wrong with the world?
This article is not about your parents. Did you read it?

I think you conflate taking the coin as a deposit, which I believe the Fed has to do under 12 usc 391, with then creating Federal Reserve Notes on account of it ,which is completely within the Fed's discretion. . As I read 12 usc 391, 412 & 414, there is nothing in any of them that obligates the Fed to go beyond taking the deposit. It does not have to create Federal Reserve Notes in an equal amount and let Tsy issue them into the economy as and when Tsy decides to do so by writing checks.

The deposit is safe and Tsy can always get it back so the essence of a depository relationship is intact.. Thus there is no conflict over the deposit. Treasury does not sustain any losses because of any Fed refusal to allow Tsy to monetize the coin. Any damage is, by hypothesis, fully compensated by giving the coin back.

The Fed's legal position here is curious. Why does the Fed have a billion unwanted $1 coins in its vault if its had the authority all along to refuse coins its member banks never ordered? If Tsy can put a billion $1 coins to the Fed, it can put a single $1 billion coin to the Fed. Once you accept that point, as the joke goes, we're just negotiating about price.
I've never heard of the Fed refusing the deposit of legal tender by anyone (they may make you put your pennies in rolls but they will accept it), If the Fed governors start by refusing the Secretary of the Treasury's deposit of lawful money, they'd destroy the independence of the Federal Reserve. The conflicting powers would trigger the Secretary's "subject to the supervision and control" authority over the Fed (12 USC 246).
Of course only we Republicans believe in Eisenhower's point that sometimes the way to solve an insoluble problem is to make it bigger. I don't think it'd ever occur to a Democratic Administration that the first step to winning the debt ceiling war against the GOP House involves launching a preemptive strike against the Fed.
Carlos Mucha
25-Across?  "Ethnic restaurant" is offensive?  Can you explain?
Wait a minute, gun owners are now 'the few' and victims of mass-shootings are 'the many'? We're through the looking-glass now folks.
I won't vote for any legislator that DOESN'T have an F or D rating from the NRA.

In my experience, only manipulators and semi-educated people use the word "society." This contribution presents an emotionally charged argument with little willingness to understand the reason why Americans have the right to bear arms. Tim B. is also demonizing the NRA, effectively throwing a rubber bone to the dogs to chew upon.

Underemployment, losing one's home, catastrophically inadequate education, and poor/inadequate health care threaten the average American more than guns do, but guns provide some power (which is why Hitler collected and banned them immediately after seizing power), while Americans gain literally nothing from the other, more threatening forms of disempowerment.

It is time for Americans to ask themselves, how much of their power they are willing to give up for a false premise of security. They have hardly any power left and what they have (the jury system, the right to bear arms, organizing grassroots and referendums), they seem to misunderstand, ignore, simply not know, or even learn to hate. Did I forget the Free Speech? No, political correctness have long overhauled and virtually annihilated it.

This legislation moves light years in the direction of sensible gun regulations. Weapons of war, with minor modifications by manufacturers so that they can slip through older regulations, have no place in American society.

Our nation was based on ideals of personal liberties but not to the detriment and harm of the majority of its citizens. The NRA with its cry baby tactics, appealing to all who will listen with its embrace of a gun in every household and in every hand, is waning in its influence. Today again, another not so veiled threat from that organization that they will let legislators know where they stand with the gun rights lobby.

If I were a legislator, I would embrace and F rating from that disreputable group. Since when are the rights of a few who crave semi automatic weapons greater than the rights of innocents and children?

Please stop blowing hot air. Pakistan is certainly not as what you seem to portray. If Pakistanis were hostile towards Americans, then Apple stores and other American food franchises like McDonalds, Dunkin' Donuts, Pizza Hut, Subway, KFC, Fat burger, Johnny Rockets, Domino's Pizza, Hardee's etc wouldn't be popular in Pakistan.

Pakistan is a vibrant country, with over 110 million cell phone users and with 90 domestic television channels. Pakistan has a free media and judiciary right now. No reason to worry or hyperventilate about Pakistan right now.

Pakistan Chief Justice is a recipient of the Medal of Freedom from Harvard Law School, along with Nelson Mandela and one other person. He knows how to hold corrupt people like this prime minister accountable.

corection:  San jose is about 3500 feet above sea level,  The surrounding mountains are about 5000 but the city itself nests in the Central Valley.  However in contrast to th coastal areas the climate is temperate and in the dry season when the winds blow it  can drop into the fifties during the evening

This says San Jose has altitude of 3809 ft:

http://costarica.com/san-jose/

Whereas Denver is truly the mile high city at 5280 ft.

Cold may be a home field advantage for the US, but to the extent Costa Rica uses players from their domestic league, San Jose is at about the same altitude as Denver (4900 feet or so).

As to the afternoon heat in Mexico City, March/April are the warmest months, but the average high is still only 78 degrees. It is the altitude (which explains the temperature) and smog that get you, not the heat.
Jolley - Gee, some of the piker retinue may think it's not cricket to introduce one more fish joke.
Yesterday, while we were all exchanging fish jokes, a young Major League Baseball star made the news by catching a 500 lb. grouper off Key West.  Which player?  Mike Trout.

Thanks, TJ, for stepping up to the MIKE and TROUTing out that interesting sound BYTE.

H

Actually, I was rather TAKEN by this Hump Day offering from Michael David, that provided the soothing BAUM I DEEREly need, knowing the next rather unpleasant Appt. on my calendar here in Quincy is with a D.D.S. that would normally give yours truly an EFFn PFFT!

Howie gives this XWDP a perfect TIN!

"When someone in Likkud, or in NY, says the same things about Muslims, Arabs and Palestinians, the NYTimes dismisses it out of hand."

Probably because certainly no one in Likud leadership has ever said anything remotely similar or they would be thrown under the bus. In NY plenty of people say plenty of stuff about everyone ... but they aren't leaders of a country with 85 million people speaking on TV - and finally you can be sure if an Arab boy gets nosebleed the Guardian and BBC will be writing and broadcasting, the UN will call a special meeting and the EU will discuss boycotts ... you can't get away with making silly statements that every one knows are accurate descriptions but of the Muslim Arabs and not Israel who is lambasted everyday from every direction

The deficit was caused by unfunded wars, tax cuts, and a major financial crisis causing a quasi-depression.

The rising cost of health care can be addressed by reasonable measures, including appropriate standards of care, and providing funding sources for previously 'uninsured' who rely on emergency rooms, both addressed to a degree by Obamacare, but should not be blamed for the deficit.

First, to lead the country, President Obama had to first win reelection.

Second, it is the rsing cost of health care that is driving the deficit, not "entitlements."

Third, everything you want the president to do has been met with GOP obstructionism.

Fourth, next Tuesday, filibuster reform will come up for a vote and the Merkley/Udall plan must pass if anything is to get done. Reid is considering the awful McCain/Levin plan which really just maintains the status quo. There is less than a week to contact every Democratic Senator, especially Harry Reid, so we can get real reform. Call, write, email if you support it as many times as you can. If it does not come up for a vote next week, it can't come up again until 2014.

Mr. Friedman, if you really want change, you might want to contact the Senate, too. Otherwise, we will have four more years of nothing getting done.

You seem to forget that Republicans vilified Bill and Hillary Clinton throughout the Clinton presidency. Remember the standoff between President Clinton and House Speaker Newt Gingrich? Remember how Republicans accused Hillary Clinton of murdering Vince Foster? How about the time Congress impeached President Clinton? The list goes on.
I recall the tone in Washington during the Clinton presidency being just as toxic as it is today. It wasn't Bill Clinton's fault then, and it isn't Barack Obama's fault now.
No, the problem is the extremists who have come to dominate the Republican party in over the last couple of decades. They will do everything they can to undermine and delegitimize any Democratic president whom voters elect.

In this society, we're much more critical of black behavior than others. That's what this is all about. The president doesn't behave like our stereotype of a "typical" black person. Besides black men in hoodies, a self-possessed, confident black man scares the boots off folks. Do you think that schmoozing with the Republicans would change their opinion of President Obama? They're obstructing him because they're steamed that a black man is president. That's it. That's all. This is not complex. Maureen has some kind of high school vendetta against the president.

One man's tenacity is another man's nagging: I for one am really tired of Maureen's constant harping on Mr. Obama's personality. We get that you and he are not close. Maybe he snubbed you; I wouldn't know, but please, move on to matters of more substance- or less substance but something fresh. Please.

I admire your tenacity, Maureen. President Obama is more reclusive and less available than Bill Clinton was, something brought home to me when former president Clinton addressed the Democratic convention. As Barack has said, Clinton is 'the master'.

Having the kinds of skills which Bill had and has do go a long way toward achieving things in Washington. It is the rare individual who has those skills and genuinely seems able to cross the aisle, though I wonder if he would be quite as able in these days of intransigent Republicans.

But one thing is certain, which you allude to, is that having Willard as president would have unleashed changes unfavorable to all, except the wealthy and those of his inner sanctum. Thank God that President Obama will be inaugurated, the alternative is almost too frightening to contemplate.

Instead of looking for somewhat obscure quotes that you haven't backed up, why don't you deal with the obviously racist, anti-Semtic, and insane comments made by the leader of the most populous Arab states? And the fact that these play well for him at home?  Don't divert this issue; it is not the lissue at hand.

Kishke's comment above at 5:57 replying to Andrew's attempt at widening the frame of reference for the voice of bigotry in different media cultures, is wrong
as Andrew's observation is sadly, correct. In Israel there is so much not translated from the Hebrew press into English for fear of alienating diaspora support of any Israeli government, including that of current PM Netanyahu's coalition which has voiced anti-American sentiment and condescension towards Pres. Obama. As a Hebrew reader I can tell you that comments made by recently indicted Foreign Minister Avigdor Lieberman come close to Morsi's in racism, not only anti-Arab but also anti-dark-skinned Jewish or Israeli bigotry as well. Lieberman is not alone. See some of the public comments about Jews from North Africa or the Arab world in columns by Interior Minister Eli Yishai, or in previous Israeli governments comments made by assasinated Tourism Minister Rehavam "Gandhi" Ze'evi or Israel's man by Noriega's side, "Mad Mike" Harari back in the 1980's. Giza'anuth or racism is a common modality in Hebrew mass media, and to its credit the critics of such are given the space to rebut. Acknowledging begins reforming. Dennial ain't just a river in Egypt!

Don't offer to pay for extra' Fries, either.!

They were asking for 'spending cuts', r,member??

If Obama were LBJ or any other person,, it wouldn't make any difference to the GOPers. They don't like him: never did.

It is not that Obama was reelected;. He was reelected over solid opposition from GOP who frustrated him so much for 4 years on so many issues. They never wanted him in 2008 in the first place, and when he surprised them, one of their leaders vowed to make him a "one-term president.."

Remember this, Mr. Prez ! No use worrying about emulating LBJ. You've accomplished things anyone of your predecessors would be proud of,, and you've 4 more years to do what you couldn't in the first term. Let' em go to MacDonald's.
Wish you (ans us) ALL the best in the 2nd term.

It seems that everybody is always calling it on Pakistan.  By my count, it's died at least ten times since it was born.  Granted, it ain't Switzerland.  But, then, Texas and other political monstrosities ain't, either.  The important thing for us is to keep tiptoeing away.  Pakistan can only hurt itself--or at worst, also hurt India.  And India can definitely take care of itself.
There are few countries more dysfunctional than Pakistan.

Pakistan is more of a terrorist camp than a country! Total chaos... Not one government has completed its term in Pakistan since its Independence! And if you think that the Muslim terrorists are spreading terror against Hindus, Christians and Jews...its not just that. The Muslims in Pakistan are fighting among themselves! I wish they get some brains and think of being a country and resurrect themselves and be humans rather than concentrating on poking India and helping terrorists.
there is no country more sweet then Pakistan.
